Although defeated in the first
game of the season, the 'Varsity
football team gave promise of
rounding into a most creditable aggregation. On Saturday, however,
it was no match for the seasoned
team of the Maryland Agricultural
College; the final result being 26
to o.
The Aggies had a fast, heavy
team, and played good football
from the start. It was their third
victory of the season in • as many
games, while many of the 'Varsity
had had only a single week's practice.
• The game started with Tippett
kicking off to the Aggies, who immediately began things with a rush,
and scored the first touchdown in
four plays. The ball was carried
over by Morris, and after a punt out
from the corner of the field, Shipley
kicked an easy goal.
At the next kick-off the 'Varsity
braced and held the Aggies scoreless until the middle of the third
quarter. The Black and Blue was
mainly on the defensive, however,
kicking whenever it had the ball in
its own territory. It was in the first
quarter, soon after the Aggies' first
touchdown, that the 'Varsity had its
only chance to score. Tippett intercepted one of the Aggies forward
passes on his thirty-yard line, and
by clever running advanced the ball
to the middle of the field. Line
plunges forwarded the ball nine
yards more in three plays, and
Chunn made it first down on the
next. A Hopkins man was off side,
however, and the ball was brought
back. Fulton gave the signal for
a placement kick, but the distance
was too great, and Wilkinson's effort went wide. After this, Hopkins failed to do any offensive work.
In the middle of the third quarter,
the Aggies started once more and
rushed the ball to the ten-yard line.
Here the 'Varsity braced up, and on
the first two downs the Aggies did
not gain. On the third th - y made
a bit, while Knode carried the ball
over for the second touchdown on
the next play. Shipley kicked goal.
The next touchdown followed
Closely. Tippett kicked to Shipley
on the Aggies' forty-yard line.
Ruff made a beautiful run to our
forty-yard line around left end until
he was downed by Tippett. Tippett
figured in a similar play when Shipley took the ball to the ten-yard line.
Morris took the ball over after two
downs, going through leftend and
tackle. Shipley failed at goal.
The fourth touchdown was made

The annual opening reception of
the Johns Ho-kins Young Men's
Christian Association was held in
Levering Hall on Friday 'evening,
October io. A large number of
students from all of the classes of
the University, as well as, several
members of the faculty, was present; and, as is usually the case at
these gatherings, t h e freshman
class was especially well represented.
Dr. R. V. D. Magoffin, as president of the Y. M. C. A., after an
interesting introductory speech, announced that Mr. Eugene Lever,
ing, a trustee of the University and
the donor of Levering Hall, would
be the first speaker. Mr. Levering
spoke mainly on the benefits that a
college course can be to the student, and gave some very good advice as to how a man should gain
these benefits, emphasizing t h e
work of the Y. M. C. A. as a great
helping agent in the students' university life.
Following Mr. Levering, students representative of the many
lines of activity in the University
spoke. Mr. Sutton gave a very
graphic and appealing talk on the
work of the Y. M. C. A., especially
along lines of Bible study and missions. Messrs. Gillet and Huck
urged the men to show their college
spirit by supporting the athletic
teams in whatever way they could.
Mr. Corner, in a very well delivered
and interesting speech, told about
the Eaglesmere Conference, and
urged all men who might find it
possible to take advantage of next
year's trip. Mr. R. J. Scovell spoke
to the freshmen, especially on the
Musical Clubs, asking them to come
out and help make the clubs a success. Mr. A. K. Barton spoke
about THE NEWS-LETTER, telling
how the students can help make it
a flourishing paper.
After the speeches were over, all
present went into the next room,
where, between plates of ice cream
and cake, yells were given and Hopkins songs sung. At a late hour the
company disbanded, with the general expression of opinion that the
reception had been a decided success in every way.

"I don't understand," wrote the
college boy home, "why you call
yourself a kind parent. I haven't
had a check from you for five
weeks. May I ask what sort of
kindness that is called?"
His father wrote back:"Unremitting kindness."

6-o, 6-4.

DOUBLES:
Hammond and Corner (H.) defeated Ford
and Gibson (M. A. C.), 6-4, 6,o.
Schnepfe and Merrick (II.) defeated Deeley
and Grey (M. A. C.), 6-4, 6-o.

The singles of the University
Closed Tennis Tournament are under way. Of the twenty-two entrants, Huck will probably meet
Binford in the upper half and
Schnepfe meet Sears in the lower.
Huck has yet to play Powers;
the winner will play Hammond,
who has already disposed of Boyce.
In the second quarter, Binford, who
has beaten Troxell and Merrick,
will reach the semi-finals if he can
defeat the winner of the PennimanChenoweth match. • In the third
quarter, Sears beat Richardson in
the first round and then defeated
Uhler, who had just beaten Catlin.
Hutzler and Sears will play for
the semi-final place. Schnepfe has
reached the semi-finals in the fourth
quarter, having disposed of Weber
and Pitt, who had beaten Howell.
Doubles and consolations begin
Monday. Among those entered in
the doubles are Huck and Rice,
Merrick and partner, Hammond
and Corner, Binford and Boyce.

consin University, to be professor

Charles Joseph Tilden, professor
of engineering mechanics at University of Michigan, to be professor
of civil engineering.
Dr. Whitehead, who becomes the
new professor of electrical engineering, has long been a figure at
the University and is well known in
scientific and educational circles. To
him was given the task of going
over the country and finding the
men best suited to build up the
Johns Hopkins Technical School.
In fulfilling this duty, he visited
more than twenty universities,
talked to the deans of the various
technical schools and sized up the
men likely to be called to the work
in Baltimore. It was on his recommendation that the men were called.
He is a Virginian, and received his
education in applied electricity at
Hopkins. Dr. Whitehead h a s
worked with the Westinghouse
forces, and spent a year with the
Niagara Falls Electrical Company,
which operates the giant power
plant at Niagara Falls. He has
written extensively.
Both of the new men are said
to be fine fellows and will fit in
splendidly here, combining pleasant
personalities with force and ability.

October 6—Among those who
met King George today were
Harold Hering and Emory Niles,
two Rhodes scholars from the
States.
October 7—The way that Messrs.
Niles and Hering met King George
yesterday was as follows: King
George was riding down the Strand.
at the head of a procession while
Hering and Niles were in a bus going the other way.
Once more "Aprille" is with us,
and the "vynes" are being "bathed
in licour" again, though in common
parlance the month is October and
to vulgar eyes the trees don't seem
to be getting any new leaves. Can't
we call back some alumnus like
Charles Leland Getz to stop the perpetration of such absurdities ?
Prof.—What's a skeptic?
Stud—A skeptic is a fellow who
would look for the wish-bone in a
soft-boiled egg.

BALTIMORE, MD., OCT. 13, 1913.
Welcome, 1917!

To the largest freshman class that
has ever entered our doors, THE
NEws-LETTER extends its most cordial welcome. We hope that the
importance of your class in after
years will correspond with its size.
But remember that a class is made
memorable by the individual work
that each fellow does.
Like air and water (see Poly.
Con. I), advice is "a free good."
But we want to venture some suggestions about your work as individuals, and are bold enough to say
that- your future will be materially
different, according as you heed or
disregard what follows.
First, don't spent all your time
in study. You will only insulate yourself from your fellows.
"Mixing" is the only way to study
human nature—the most interesting course offered.
Second, get into as many college
activities as you have time for—
athletics, if you have any "build"
at all; grit and stick-at-itness will
often go farther than mere weight.
-And here are suggestions for those
not athletic: THE NEWS-LETTER
will give you invaluable practice in
writing. Try the Musical Clubs if
you have three dollars; musical talent is unimportant—our method intills it. If music comes too high,
try oratory; the Grotius Society
will listen to anyone who pays one
dollar per.
From suggestions we turn to exhortation. Can you stand some?
'Cultivate the "Homewood habit:'
-Tut your soda water and theatre
money in a season ticket. It will
admit you to each game for a quarter. When at Homewood, )(ELL. A
man who won't support his football
team is without qualities that perfect recitations, and good marks
cannot atone for.

The Cheering Section.

The spirit shown during Saturday's game was most praiseworthy.
But there were too many fellows,
upper classmen especially, who did
not appear in the cheering section,
and the men whO did turn up didn't
half know the yells.
As Washington and Lee defeated
St. John's 19 to 0, next Saturday's
game promises to be a stiff one. It
is up to every man in the University, who can play football, to come
out this week and make the team a
success.
And those of us who make up the
rooting section must "come across"
with our share. Saturday will be
a good day to put into practice that
choice motto of the Booster Club:
"Root or be rooted."
The Interfraternity Agreement.

The new interfraternity agreement has received the signatures of
the six fraternities and becomes the
common code by which they are
bound. Last year was the first time
that such an agreement was tried
here. It was then universally acknowledged to be highly satisfactory and desirable, although in its
detail many points needed more
careful working out and less ambiguous wording. Upon this task
of reconstruction the Interfraternity
Board has been working continuously since last April and has just
come to an agreement. In this process practically every fraternity has
found it necessary to sacrifice some
favorite principle for the betterment of -fraternity conditions at
Hopkins; and, although at times it
has gone extremely hard with some,
an excellent spirit of pulling together has been shown.
The object of the agreement is to
eliminate rushing from prep.schools
and to wipe out the evils of the
system of several years ago, under
which men were often pledged to fraternities before they realized
their significance or had opportunity
to compare their merits.
The document is concise and plain
and should be carefully studied by
all interested in it, and its details
strictly adhered to.
And the interfraternity agreement
deserves the commendation of the
entire University. It is indicative
of the spirit with which the fraternities regard our University—the
sacrifice of selfish fraternity interests for the good of our University
at large. It shows that the fraternities regard the questions of rushing
from the standpoint of the freshmen, as well as from their own
standpoints, and desire to do the
right thing by them. Finally, it
shows the Hopkins get-together
spirit in marked contrast to any
factionalism or cliquishness. The
agreement has now passed through
its period of probation, and is here
to stay for the good of Johns Hopkins.

fore gallins of bere will fill thirtyto pint bottles, how many pint and

and sed he wouldn't go back

then we went and borrowed a lot

there were nineteen, and my boy

don't know whether it is rite or

water, as I am not able to buy any

SECTION 1. Until the first Monday after the Y. M. C. A. Reception of
the year in which he enters the University, no candidate shall be rushed
by any fraternity in any of the following ways:
1) Allowing candidates within fraternity houses.
(2) Taking candidates to theatre parties, athletic games and other
similar functions.
(3) Speaking to a candidate or candidates concerning fraternity matters
under any circumstances.

The qualifying examinations for

Maryland will be held here in the
University on Tuesday and Wednesday, October 14 and 15. All who

referred to the Maryland committee of selection. The elected scholar

in October, 1914. The scholarship
is worth $1,500 per annum.
Examinations will be held again
in 1916 and 1917.

A BUREAU OF APPOINTMENTS
A Committee of the Faculty in Charge.
Should Prove Benefit to Self-Supporting Students and Others.

Upon recommendation of the Administrative Committee, the Board
of Trustees of the University has
authorized a Bureau of Appointments. The work of this new bureau will be administered by a faculty committee, the chairman of
which is Dr. Ralph V. D. Magoffin.
Its functions will be three-fold:
First, it will endeavor to place in
good positions, both academic and
non-academic, all worthy graduates
of the departments of art, science
and engineering. It will keep a
tabulated record of all graduating
students who desire positions; it will
correspond with prospective employers and make to them definite
recommendations upon the advice
of the teaching staff of the various
departments of the University, and
through them becoming a sort of
University clearing-house for graduates, thus hoping to give the University more rapid, economic and
satisfactory service.
Second, the Bureau of Appointments expects to establish relations
with as many alumni of the University as possible, in order that it
may recommend the successful or
dissatisfied to better or more suitable positions.; also, that it may learn
from them Of new positions which
it may fill and that it may enlist the
interest of nearby alumni in the
plans to help self-supporting students in the University.
Third, the Bureau of Appointments will conduct an office for the
purpose of assisting students who
wish, or who find it necessary, to
become partly self-supporting. It
has already delegated to the general
secretary of the University Y. M.
C. A. the more intimate and personal management of this part of
its activities. Notices of various
kinds will appear on the University
bulletin boards. Alumni and friends
of the University are invited to avail
themselves of the services of the
Bureau of Appointments to secure
earnest and able young men for
short-term time or entire summertime employment. No charges
whatever are to be made by the
Bureau of Appointments for its
services.

Acquisition to French Department.

The French department has been
enriched by the acquisition of two
new men—Prof. Andre Morize and
M. Raymond Leguy. Prof. Morize is filling the place made vacant by the resignation last spring
of Prof. L. A. Terracher, who left
here to accept the professorship of
French at the University of Liverpool.
Dr. Morize comes to serve as assistant professor of French literature. He is a Frenchman by birth,
and received the degree of agrege
es lettres in 1908 from the University of Paris. On leaving that institution, he occupied a chair in the
Lycee at Montauban until 1911, and
since then has been ,professor at the
Bordeaux Lycee, at both of which
places he had an exceptional record
as a teacher.
Prof. Morize is the author of
many studies in French literature,
especially that of the eighteenth
century, and is now engaged in
publishing critical editions of various works of Voltaire. He is held
in high esteem by French scholars,
and is considered an authority in
his line. He has already arrived to
take up his work here, all of which
will be in connection with graduate
courses.
M. Raymond Leguy is a native
of France, and studied at the
Lycee de Laval from 1901 to 1908.
He received the degree of bachelier
es lettres in Latin and the modern
languages from the 'University of
Rennes. From 19o8 to 1910 he
studied at the Lycee Louis le Grand.
and in the latter year he became interne at the Ecole Normale Superieure.
In 1913, he received the degree
of licensie es lettres in the English
literature and language from the
University of Paris, and also that
of diplome des etudes superieures.
M. Leguy has studied a year in
London, so that he is now thoroughly at ease in the English language. He holds a traveling fellowship from the trench government. He was engaged last summer by the authorities of the University to give undergraduate and
graduate instruction in 'French.

THE NEWS—LETTER, OCTOBER 13, 1913.
Reed's New Book on Football.

UNIVERSITY CALENDAR

One of the best books on football which has ever been written
has just been published by the
Frederick A. Stokes Company,
New York. Herbert Reed, the
author, has had twenty years' experience as a player, college coach,
and as an expert writer for the
New York Evening Post and Evening Sun.
It is intended primarily for the
spectator, but it contains a number
of formations and expert suggestions, which will be of great benefit to those who play the game. It
teaches the game by the novel
method of comparing it to warfare,
and pointing out its similarities and
differences. There are also a large
number of photographs of teams
in action, some of which are large
college elevens, and some of which
are preparatory schools teams.
Everyone who plays the game or
takes the slightest interest in it will
like this excellent work. It is the
only book of its kind that has appeared in many years, and fills a
large place in American sporting
literature.

BALTIMORE

University Track Team.

The track team has taken a new
departure this year in beginning
work during the fall term. An interclass meet has been set for October 25, at Homewood, at which a
silver loving cup is offered as a
perpetual trophy to bear the numerals of the winning classes. This
meet will not displace the annual
indoor meet between the freshmen
and the sophomores, either in interest or importance, but will serve as
an incentive for three weeks' practice to draw out freshman track
men who are not playing football.
The usual events will be on the
program. Joseph T. England will
continue his work as head coach,
and a corps of graduate assistants
will be announced later.
The cross country team will be
definitely organized during the week
and work in conjunction with the
track team durinv the fall will be
announced. Captain Wagner is
busy trying to bring this activity
bad( into prominence at Hopkins.
The first practice was held on Saturday in the form of light road work
along Charles Street avenue with
a good number of men participating. Freshmen are to be encouraged to attend the runs this week,
even men who have never run before.

THE NEWS—LETTER, OCTOBER 13, 1913.

TRANSFORMATION OF ARCADIA
Unique Salon in the Basement of McCoy
Hall Has Undergone Many Changes
During the Past Summer.

Once an oasis for the indigent
student—a place where he might
have fled from academic scenes,
from museums and mummies, from
physics and philosophy, for a quiet
moment and a peaceful breath of
lavender and old rose perfume—
Walter's barber shop, that antique
salon in the basement of McCoy
Hall, has been subtly transformed
during the summer into a gallery
of ancient photographs and engravings of the faculty, individually and
collectively, making it, in short, an
utterly unrestful and unwholesome
retreat for the "cronies" who used
to call it home.
Not that the pictures themselves
produce this effect. They are of
"worthy men with-alle." It is the
connotation (get the Eng. Comp.
I). That barber shop lasted through
a quarter of a century without the
touch of academic finger. It was
delightful. No shelves of books,
no teaching pulpits, nothing to remind one of study.
But, ah!
One August morn its Portuguese
supervisor unearthed in the garret
of McCoy Hall a splendid array of
portraits in dusty solicitude. There
were so many, he thought he
couldn't get them all in his shop.
But he did. There isn't a square
inch on the walls uncovered by some
learned countenance; and today the
Place terrifies our brain-racked student.
To get shaved is a horror. The
face is shifted to the left, that the
razor can work on the level. Four
feet dead ahead is the picture of
a
professor who then combed his
whiskers in the middle, while now
the stroke is north
and
gaze is enough. The south. One
eye (the other
is full of soap)
then falls on the
Venezuela Commission, and so on
ad lib.
The face is shifted
Here comes the silver to the right.
lining of the
cloud. In a group of the eighteenth
century faculty, Dr. "G. Chaucer"
Greene is seen affecting a beard
after the Marquis of Queensber
ry
fashion.
Below is a wood-cut of the
Frenchman who invented the surd.
Above, a zinc etching of Guy de
Lussac. Get pictures of Lucretia
Borgia and Henry the Confessor
and the effect will be complete.
It's all too much, Walter. Too
much to expect young "doctors" to
Sit in your chair, gaze
of Dr. Rowland, and into the face
then have to
browse thoughtfully in spectroscopical pastures. Too much that
they
have to look at Paul Haupt and go
off into some sweet Semitic dream.
"Mister," inquired Weary Willie,
would you contribute a dollar to
help beautify your thriving city ?"
"Sure! What's the idea?"
"A dollar will buy me a ticket to
the next town."

Harvard Boy Scouts.

THE NEWS-LETTER'S MAIL BAG

The Boy Scout movement is such
a success elsewhere, why not have
a Hopkins troop? There ought to
be good material in 1917.
One of the Scout laws is to be
helpful. .A.Scout must do at least
one good turn to somebody every
day—this is what the Harvard boys
have done, acc9rding to the Harvard
Lampoon:
1. Rudolph Rumble, crossing
Harvard Bridge, saw an old man's
hat blow off in front of an auto.
Running in front of the machine,
Rudolph kicked the hat into the
river, saving it from being crushed
beneath the .wheels.
2. Bobbie Butt noticed a young
negro standing on the third-story
ledge of a building washing windows, and called to him to look out.
The lad turned, fell, and broke his
leg. Had he not been warned he
would undoubtedly have broken his
neck.
3. Harry Wrinkle perceived an
infant playing about the front steps
of a large apartment house. He
took the child to the police station
and locked it up, where the grateful mother found it three days
later. The child might otherwise
have strayed away, causing the
parents hours of needless. anxiety.
4. Willie Wobble noticed a grocery horse standing beside the curb,
perspiring freely. He unhitched
the animal, led it home, and gave it
a cool, witch-hazel sponge-bath,
followed by a good meal of mashed
potatoes. The owner may get his
horse by going out to Willie's house
in South Weymouth.
5. Clarence Cod saw an elderly
lady about to step on the hem of
her dress at the entrance to the subway. Rushing to her, he pushed
her over on her back, thereby, in
all probability, saving her a nasty
fall downstairs.
6. Phreddie Phutt perceived a
laborer sitting on a bale of straw
smoking a pipe. With great presence of mind he seized a bucket of
water and wet down both the man
and the straw thoroughly, thus allowing the honest fellow to enjoy
his pipe without further risk of fire.

EXCLUSIVE
IDEAS

A Column in Which the Correspondents
Are Allowed Latitude, but Shoulder the Responsibility.
"Emperor of the West" Elucidates.

October II, 1913.
THE NEWS-LETTER:
The freshmen are not the only
ones who need a little advice now
and then. I think that the sophomore class can stand an admonitory
elocution also. The matter is about
the hazing indulged in on "freshman day"—last Monday. I regret
sincerely that the sophomores have
not fallen in entirely with the deanic
spirit of neighborly love. Knowest
not, soph, that the freshie is thy
neighbor? Thou shouldest foster
and protect the budding genius, and
not mortify and flubricate him; yea,
even to the point of climbing lamp
posts and pushing two-wheeled gocarts — verily, servile and menial
tasks, as it were. I can only say
that I hope that when this year's
freshmen become sophs, they will
return good for evil and show the
proper way of treating freshies.
Let me not, however, be misunderstood. I have nothing at all
to say against the solemn rites and
ceremonies of initiation. This is, indeed, an ancient and sacred custom.
I verily believe that no freshman
would feel himself a true "bone
fide" matriculate, had he not been
duly initiated. The initiation ceremonies are varied from year to year,
so that there may be no aspluavistic
monotony. One time-honored ceremony strikes me as being well
worthy of continued observance—
namely, the washing in the pool of
Mt. Vernon. These annual ablutions have quite an impressive symbolism. The freshman enters Hopkins soiled and marred by contact
with the sordid world. He is full
of vain thoughts of cribs, "cuties,"
tango, etc. Quite right would it be
for him to beseech the manent
soph : "Wash me, that I may
be whiter than snow." Then the
latter will sternly reply: "Get in the
fountain, fool." The freshman
obeys and returns refreshed in body,
soul and spirit. The symbolic autohydrating, as already said, is well
worthy of continued observance.
May the custom never languish!
To the Editor of

The Worker for the Summer.
If your waiter seems a little new and
green
At the summer place you've chosen
for the season,
if the porter `has a cultivated mien—
iiiere's a reason, gentle reader, there's
a reason
If you find a stableman is up in Greek,
And the clerk discusses Ibsen with
each, corner,
Here's the answer to your question, ere
you speak—
He's a college student working for the
summer.
You will find him on the steamers,
scrubbing deck,
You will see him in the stokehole,
where he swelters,
You will find him picking currants by
the peck,
And he labors in the factories and
smelters;
He's the canvasser who lingers at your
door,
He's a trolley-car conductor and a
plumber,
And 'the extra clerk who serves you at
the store
Is a college student working for the
summer.
The iceman—you had best be kind to
him,
For he may be champion strong man
of his college.
And the girl you hire to keep the house
in trim
May be Vassar's very pride and full
of knowledge.
There is nothing that a student won't
essay;
He's a willing little toiler and a hummer;
You will find him near at home or far
away—
The college student working for the
summer.

—BURTON BRALEY.

Although defeated in the first

football team gave promise of
rounding into a most creditable aggregation. On Saturday, however,
it was no match for the seasoned
team of the Maryland Agricultural
College; the final result being 26
to o.
The Aggies had a fast, heavy
team, and played good football
from the start. It was their third
victory of the season in • as many
games, while many of the 'Varsity
had had only a single week's practice.
• The game started with Tippett
kicking off to the Aggies, who immediately began things with a rush,
and scored the first touchdown in
four plays. The ball was carried
over by Morris, and after a punt out
from the corner of the field, Shipley
kicked an easy goal.
At the next kick-off the 'Varsity
braced and held the Aggies scoreless until the middle of the third
quarter. The Black and Blue was
mainly on the defensive, however,
kicking whenever it had the ball in
its own territory. It was in the first
quarter, soon after the Aggies' first
touchdown, that the 'Varsity had its
only chance to score. Tippett intercepted one of the Aggies forward
passes on his thirty-yard line, and
by clever running advanced the ball
to the middle of the field. Line
plunges forwarded the ball nine
yards more in three plays, and

The annual opening reception of
the Johns Ho-kins Young Men's
Christian Association was held in
Levering Hall on Friday 'evening,
October io. A large number of
students from all of the classes of
the University, as well as, several
members of the faculty, was present; and, as is usually the case at
these gatherings, t h e freshman
class was especially well represented.
Dr. R. V. D. Magoffin, as president of the Y. M. C. A., after an
interesting introductory speech, announced that Mr. Eugene Lever,
ing, a trustee of the University and
the donor of Levering Hall, would
be the first speaker. Mr. Levering
spoke mainly on the benefits that a
college course can be to the student, and gave some very good advice as to how a man should gain
these benefits, emphasizing t h e
work of the Y. M. C. A. as a great
helping agent in the students' university life.
Following Mr. Levering, students representative of the many
lines of activity in the University
spoke. Mr. Sutton gave a very
graphic and appealing talk on the
work of the Y. M. C. A., especially
along lines of Bible study and missions. Messrs. Gillet and Huck
urged the men to show their college
spirit by supporting the athletic
teams in whatever way they could.
Mr. Corner, in a very well delivered
and interesting speech, told about
the Eaglesmere Conference, and
urged all men who might find it
possible to take advantage of next
year's trip. Mr. R. J. Scovell spoke
to the freshmen, especially on the
Musical Clubs, asking them to come
out and help make the clubs a success. Mr. A. K. Barton spoke
about THE NEWS-LETTER, telling
how the students can help make it
a flourishing paper.
After the speeches were over, all
present went into the next room,
where, between plates of ice cream
and cake, yells were given and Hopkins songs sung. At a late hour the
company disbanded, with the general expression of opinion that the
reception had been a decided success in every way.

Schnepfe and Merrick (II.) defeated Deeley
and Grey (M. A. C.), 6-4, 6-o.

The singles of the University
Closed Tennis Tournament are under way. Of the twenty-two entrants, Huck will probably meet
Binford in the upper half and
Schnepfe meet Sears in the lower.
Huck has yet to play Powers;
the winner will play Hammond,
who has already disposed of Boyce.
In the second quarter, Binford, who
has beaten Troxell and Merrick,
will reach the semi-finals if he can
defeat the winner of the PennimanChenoweth match. • In the third
quarter, Sears beat Richardson in
the first round and then defeated
Uhler, who had just beaten Catlin.
Hutzler and Sears will play for
the semi-final place. Schnepfe has
reached the semi-finals in the fourth
quarter, having disposed of Weber
and Pitt, who had beaten Howell.
Doubles and consolations begin
Monday. Among those entered in
the doubles are Huck and Rice,
Merrick and partner, Hammond
and Corner, Binford and Boyce.

BALTIMORE, MD., OCT. 13, 1913.
Welcome, 1917!

To the largest freshman class that
has ever entered our doors, THE
NEws-LETTER extends its most cordial welcome. We hope that the
importance of your class in after
years will correspond with its size.
But remember that a class is made
memorable by the individual work
that each fellow does.
Like air and water (see Poly.
Con. I), advice is "a free good."
But we want to venture some suggestions about your work as individuals, and are bold enough to say
that- your future will be materially
different, according as you heed or
disregard what follows.
First, don't spent all your time
in study. You will only insulate yourself from your fellows.
"Mixing" is the only way to study
human nature—the most interesting course offered.
Second, get into as many college
activities as you have time for—
athletics, if you have any "build"
at all; grit and stick-at-itness will
often go farther than mere weight.
-And here are suggestions for those
not athletic: THE NEWS-LETTER
will give you invaluable practice in
writing. Try the Musical Clubs if
you have three dollars; musical talent is unimportant—our method intills it. If music comes too high,
try oratory; the Grotius Society
will listen to anyone who pays one
dollar per.
From suggestions we turn to exhortation. Can you stand some?
'Cultivate the "Homewood habit:'
-Tut your soda water and theatre
money in a season ticket. It will
admit you to each game for a quarter. When at Homewood, )(ELL. A
man who won't support his football
team is without qualities that perfect recitations, and good marks
cannot atone for.

The Cheering Section.

The spirit shown during Saturday's game was most praiseworthy.
But there were too many fellows,
upper classmen especially, who did
not appear in the cheering section,
and the men whO did turn up didn't
half know the yells.
As Washington and Lee defeated
St. John's 19 to 0, next Saturday's
game promises to be a stiff one. It
is up to every man in the University, who can play football, to come
out this week and make the team a
success.
And those of us who make up the
rooting section must "come across"
with our share. Saturday will be
a good day to put into practice that
choice motto of the Booster Club:
"Root or be rooted."
The Interfraternity Agreement.

The new interfraternity agreement has received the signatures of
the six fraternities and becomes the
common code by which they are
bound. Last year was the first time
that such an agreement was tried
here. It was then universally acknowledged to be highly satisfactory and desirable, although in its
detail many points needed more
careful working out and less ambiguous wording. Upon this task
of reconstruction the Interfraternity
Board has been working continuously since last April and has just
come to an agreement. In this process practically every fraternity has
found it necessary to sacrifice some
favorite principle for the betterment of -fraternity conditions at
Hopkins; and, although at times it
has gone extremely hard with some,
an excellent spirit of pulling together has been shown.
The object of the agreement is to
eliminate rushing from prep.schools
and to wipe out the evils of the
system of several years ago, under
which men were often pledged to fraternities before they realized
their significance or had opportunity
to compare their merits.
The document is concise and plain
and should be carefully studied by
all interested in it, and its details
strictly adhered to.
And the interfraternity agreement
deserves the commendation of the
entire University. It is indicative
of the spirit with which the fraternities regard our University—the
sacrifice of selfish fraternity interests for the good of our University
at large. It shows that the fraternities regard the questions of rushing
from the standpoint of the freshmen, as well as from their own
standpoints, and desire to do the
right thing by them. Finally, it
shows the Hopkins get-together
spirit in marked contrast to any
factionalism or cliquishness. The
agreement has now passed through
its period of probation, and is here
to stay for the good of Johns Hopkins.

A teacher received the following
from a complaining parent a few
days ago:
Sir—Will you please for the future give my boy some eesier somes
to do nites. This is what he brought
home two or three nites ago: if
fore gallins of bere will fill thirtyto pint bottles, how many pint and
half bottles will nine gallins fill?
Well, we tried, and could make
nothing of it all, and my boy cried
and sed he wouldn't go back
without doing it. So I had to go
an buy a nine-gallin keg of bere,
which I could ill afford to do, and
then we went and borrowed a lot
of wine and brandy bottles, besides
a few we had by us. Well, we
emptied the keg into the bottles and
there were nineteen, and my boy
put that down for an answer. I
don't know whether it is rite or
not, as we spilt some in doing it.
P. S.—Please let the next one be
water, as I am not able to buy any
ni()re bere.—Ex.

SECTION 1. Until the first Monday after the Y. M. C. A. Reception of
the year in which he enters the University, no candidate shall be rushed
by any fraternity in any of the following ways:
1) Allowing candidates within fraternity houses.
(2) Taking candidates to theatre parties, athletic games and other
similar functions.
(3) Speaking to a candidate or candidates concerning fraternity matters
under any circumstances.
(The *brothers of active members are excepted from this article.)
SEC. 2. On and after the first Monday following the Y. M. C. A.
Reception, any fraternity may make rushing dates with students of the
University at its own discretion, with the following exceptions, viz.: that
the number of engagements that a rushee can have with one fraternity on
either Friday or Saturday nights shall be limited to three before Thanksgiving and one after Thanksgiving. Engagements made the day before
the time of the entertainment shall be excepted from this article.
SEc. 3. During the rushing season active and alumni members of fraternities, except faculty members, shall be allowed to discuss fraternity
matters with whoever they wish, so long as they do not extend an
Invitation directly to the candidate or indirectly through someone connected with him or procure any verbal or written statement as to what
he will do on the date at which the invitations are sent out.
SEc. 4. No student shall be invited to join a fraternity at Johns Hopkins earlier than the second Monday after Thanksgiving of the year in
which he enters the University. No student who enters later than November 15 shall be invited to join a fraternity until he has been in the University thirty days.

THE NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 13, 1913.

6
A BUREAU OF APPOINTMENTS
A Committee of the Faculty in Charge.
Should Prove Benefit to Self-Supporting Students and Others.

Upon recommendation of the Administrative Committee, the Board
of Trustees of the University has
authorized a Bureau of Appointments. The work of this new bureau will be administered by a faculty committee, the chairman of
which is Dr. Ralph V. D. Magoffin.
Its functions will be three-fold:
First, it will endeavor to place in
good positions, both academic and
non-academic, all worthy graduates
of the departments of art, science
and engineering. It will keep a
tabulated record of all graduating
students who desire positions; it will
correspond with prospective employers and make to them definite
recommendations upon the advice
of the teaching staff of the various
departments of the University, and
through them becoming a sort of
University clearing-house for graduates, thus hoping to give the University more rapid, economic and
satisfactory service.
Second, the Bureau of Appointments expects to establish relations
with as many alumni of the University as possible, in order that it
may recommend the successful or
dissatisfied to better or more suitable positions.; also, that it may learn
from them Of new positions which
it may fill and that it may enlist the
interest of nearby alumni in the
plans to help self-supporting students in the University.
Third, the Bureau of Appointments will conduct an office for the
purpose of assisting students who
wish, or who find it necessary, to
become partly self-supporting. It
has already delegated to the general
secretary of the University Y. M.
C. A. the more intimate and personal management of this part of
its activities. Notices of various
kinds will appear on the University
bulletin boards. Alumni and friends
of the University are invited to avail
themselves of the services of the
Bureau of Appointments to secure
earnest and able young men for
short-term time or entire summertime employment. No charges
whatever are to be made by the
Bureau of Appointments for its
services.

Acquisition to French Department.

The French department has been
enriched by the acquisition of two
new men—Prof. Andre Morize and
M. Raymond Leguy. Prof. Morize is filling the place made vacant by the resignation last spring
of Prof. L. A. Terracher, who left
here to accept the professorship of
French at the University of Liverpool.
Dr. Morize comes to serve as assistant professor of French literature. He is a Frenchman by birth,
and received the degree of agrege
es lettres in 1908 from the University of Paris. On leaving that institution, he occupied a chair in the
Lycee at Montauban until 1911, and
since then has been ,professor at the
Bordeaux Lycee, at both of which
places he had an exceptional record
as a teacher.
Prof. Morize is the author of
many studies in French literature,
especially that of the eighteenth
century, and is now engaged in
publishing critical editions of various works of Voltaire. He is held
in high esteem by French scholars,
and is considered an authority in
his line. He has already arrived to
take up his work here, all of which
will be in connection with graduate
courses.
M. Raymond Leguy is a native
of France, and studied at the
Lycee de Laval from 1901 to 1908.
He received the degree of bachelier
es lettres in Latin and the modern
languages from the 'University of
Rennes. From 19o8 to 1910 he
studied at the Lycee Louis le Grand.
and in the latter year he became interne at the Ecole Normale Superieure.
In 1913, he received the degree
of licensie es lettres in the English
literature and language from the
University of Paris, and also that
of diplome des etudes superieures.
M. Leguy has studied a year in
London, so that he is now thoroughly at ease in the English language. He holds a traveling fellowship from the trench government. He was engaged last summer by the authorities of the University to give undergraduate and
graduate instruction in 'French.

THE NEWS—LETTER, OCTOBER 13, 1913.
Reed's New Book on Football.

UNIVERSITY CALENDAR

One of the best books on football which has ever been written
has just been published by the
Frederick A. Stokes Company,
New York. Herbert Reed, the
author, has had twenty years' experience as a player, college coach,
and as an expert writer for the
New York Evening Post and Evening Sun.
It is intended primarily for the
spectator, but it contains a number
of formations and expert suggestions, which will be of great benefit to those who play the game. It
teaches the game by the novel
method of comparing it to warfare,
and pointing out its similarities and
differences. There are also a large
number of photographs of teams
in action, some of which are large
college elevens, and some of which
are preparatory schools teams.
Everyone who plays the game or
takes the slightest interest in it will
like this excellent work. It is the
only book of its kind that has appeared in many years, and fills a
large place in American sporting
literature.

BALTIMORE

University Track Team.

The track team has taken a new
departure this year in beginning
work during the fall term. An interclass meet has been set for October 25, at Homewood, at which a
silver loving cup is offered as a
perpetual trophy to bear the numerals of the winning classes. This
meet will not displace the annual
indoor meet between the freshmen
and the sophomores, either in interest or importance, but will serve as
an incentive for three weeks' practice to draw out freshman track
men who are not playing football.
The usual events will be on the
program. Joseph T. England will
continue his work as head coach,
and a corps of graduate assistants
will be announced later.
The cross country team will be
definitely organized during the week
and work in conjunction with the
track team durinv the fall will be
announced. Captain Wagner is
busy trying to bring this activity
bad( into prominence at Hopkins.
The first practice was held on Saturday in the form of light road work
along Charles Street avenue with
a good number of men participating. Freshmen are to be encouraged to attend the runs this week,
even men who have never run before.

THE NEWS—LETTER, OCTOBER 13, 1913.

TRANSFORMATION OF ARCADIA
Unique Salon in the Basement of McCoy
Hall Has Undergone Many Changes
During the Past Summer.

Once an oasis for the indigent
student—a place where he might
have fled from academic scenes,
from museums and mummies, from
physics and philosophy, for a quiet
moment and a peaceful breath of
lavender and old rose perfume—
Walter's barber shop, that antique
salon in the basement of McCoy
Hall, has been subtly transformed
during the summer into a gallery
of ancient photographs and engravings of the faculty, individually and
collectively, making it, in short, an
utterly unrestful and unwholesome
retreat for the "cronies" who used
to call it home.
Not that the pictures themselves
produce this effect. They are of
"worthy men with-alle." It is the
connotation (get the Eng. Comp.
I). That barber shop lasted through
a quarter of a century without the
touch of academic finger. It was
delightful. No shelves of books,
no teaching pulpits, nothing to remind one of study.
But, ah!
One August morn its Portuguese
supervisor unearthed in the garret
of McCoy Hall a splendid array of
portraits in dusty solicitude. There
were so many, he thought he
couldn't get them all in his shop.
But he did. There isn't a square
inch on the walls uncovered by some
learned countenance; and today the
Place terrifies our brain-racked student.
To get shaved is a horror. The
face is shifted to the left, that the
razor can work on the level. Four
feet dead ahead is the picture of
a
professor who then combed his
whiskers in the middle, while now
the stroke is north
and
gaze is enough. The south. One
eye (the other
is full of soap)
then falls on the
Venezuela Commission, and so on
ad lib.
The face is shifted
Here comes the silver to the right.
lining of the
cloud. In a group of the eighteenth
century faculty, Dr. "G. Chaucer"
Greene is seen affecting a beard
after the Marquis of Queensber
ry
fashion.
Below is a wood-cut of the
Frenchman who invented the surd.
Above, a zinc etching of Guy de
Lussac. Get pictures of Lucretia
Borgia and Henry the Confessor
and the effect will be complete.
It's all too much, Walter. Too
much to expect young "doctors" to
Sit in your chair, gaze
of Dr. Rowland, and into the face
then have to
browse thoughtfully in spectroscopical pastures. Too much that
they
have to look at Paul Haupt and go
off into some sweet Semitic dream.
"Mister," inquired Weary Willie,
would you contribute a dollar to
help beautify your thriving city ?"
"Sure! What's the idea?"
"A dollar will buy me a ticket to
the next town."

The Boy Scout movement is such
a success elsewhere, why not have
a Hopkins troop? There ought to
be good material in 1917.
One of the Scout laws is to be
helpful. .A.Scout must do at least
one good turn to somebody every
day—this is what the Harvard boys
have done, acc9rding to the Harvard
Lampoon:
1. Rudolph Rumble, crossing
Harvard Bridge, saw an old man's
hat blow off in front of an auto.
Running in front of the machine,
Rudolph kicked the hat into the
river, saving it from being crushed
beneath the .wheels.
2. Bobbie Butt noticed a young
negro standing on the third-story
ledge of a building washing windows, and called to him to look out.
The lad turned, fell, and broke his
leg. Had he not been warned he
would undoubtedly have broken his
neck.
3. Harry Wrinkle perceived an
infant playing about the front steps
of a large apartment house. He
took the child to the police station
and locked it up, where the grateful mother found it three days
later. The child might otherwise
have strayed away, causing the
parents hours of needless. anxiety.
4. Willie Wobble noticed a grocery horse standing beside the curb,
perspiring freely. He unhitched
the animal, led it home, and gave it
a cool, witch-hazel sponge-bath,
followed by a good meal of mashed
potatoes. The owner may get his
horse by going out to Willie's house
in South Weymouth.
5. Clarence Cod saw an elderly
lady about to step on the hem of
her dress at the entrance to the subway. Rushing to her, he pushed
her over on her back, thereby, in
all probability, saving her a nasty
fall downstairs.
6. Phreddie Phutt perceived a
laborer sitting on a bale of straw
smoking a pipe. With great presence of mind he seized a bucket of
water and wet down both the man
and the straw thoroughly, thus allowing the honest fellow to enjoy
his pipe without further risk of fire.

October II, 1913.
THE NEWS-LETTER:
The freshmen are not the only
ones who need a little advice now
and then. I think that the sophomore class can stand an admonitory
elocution also. The matter is about
the hazing indulged in on "freshman day"—last Monday. I regret
sincerely that the sophomores have
not fallen in entirely with the deanic
spirit of neighborly love. Knowest
not, soph, that the freshie is thy
neighbor? Thou shouldest foster
and protect the budding genius, and
not mortify and flubricate him; yea,
even to the point of climbing lamp
posts and pushing two-wheeled gocarts — verily, servile and menial
tasks, as it were. I can only say
that I hope that when this year's
freshmen become sophs, they will
return good for evil and show the
proper way of treating freshies.
Let me not, however, be misunderstood. I have nothing at all
to say against the solemn rites and
ceremonies of initiation. This is, indeed, an ancient and sacred custom.
I verily believe that no freshman
would feel himself a true "bone
fide" matriculate, had he not been
duly initiated. The initiation ceremonies are varied from year to year,
so that there may be no aspluavistic
monotony. One time-honored ceremony strikes me as being well
worthy of continued observance—
namely, the washing in the pool of
Mt. Vernon. These annual ablutions have quite an impressive symbolism. The freshman enters Hopkins soiled and marred by contact
with the sordid world. He is full
of vain thoughts of cribs, "cuties,"
tango, etc. Quite right would it be
for him to beseech the manent
soph : "Wash me, that I may
be whiter than snow." Then the
latter will sternly reply: "Get in the
fountain, fool." The freshman
obeys and returns refreshed in body,
soul and spirit. The symbolic autohydrating, as already said, is well
worthy of continued observance.
May the custom never languish!
To the Editor of

The Worker for the Summer.
If your waiter seems a little new and
green
At the summer place you've chosen
for the season,
if the porter `has a cultivated mien—
iiiere's a reason, gentle reader, there's
a reason
If you find a stableman is up in Greek,
And the clerk discusses Ibsen with
each, corner,
Here's the answer to your question, ere
you speak—
He's a college student working for the
summer.
You will find him on the steamers,
scrubbing deck,
You will see him in the stokehole,
where he swelters,
You will find him picking currants by
the peck,
And he labors in the factories and
smelters;
He's the canvasser who lingers at your
door,
He's a trolley-car conductor and a
plumber,
And 'the extra clerk who serves you at
the store
Is a college student working for the
summer.
The iceman—you had best be kind to
him,
For he may be champion strong man
of his college.
And the girl you hire to keep the house
in trim
May be Vassar's very pride and full
of knowledge.
There is nothing that a student won't
essay;
He's a willing little toiler and a hummer;
You will find him near at home or far
away—
The college student working for the
summer.

—BURTON BRALEY.
